transcript:
and unreasonable than a little child, who, playing with the parts of a skillfully made watch, dares to say that, as he does not under- stand its use, he does not believe in the master who made it. To know Him is hard. . . . For ages, from our forefather Adam to our own day, we labor to attain that knowledge and are still infinitely far from our aim; but in our lack of understanding we see only our weak- ness and His greatness. . . ." 
Pierre listened with swelling heart, gazing into the Mason's
